title: Pigment Dispersion Syndrome & Pigmentary Glaucoma
summary: A comprehensive guide to Pigment Dispersion Syndrome (PDS), where iris pigment release can lead to Pigmentary Glaucoma in 33–50% of cases. Characterized by 'reverse pupillary block' and specific clinical signs like Krukenberg spindles and Zentmayer’s line.

branches: Release of pigment from mid-peripheral posterior surface of the iris
Posterior bowing of mid-peripheral iris rubbing against zonules
Reverse pupillary block: transient increase in IOP in the AC relative to the PC
Supported by improvement with miotics or Nd-yAG PIs
Possible second locus on Chr18q (exact genes unidentified)

sections.title: Clinical Features of PDS
content: Pigment on corneal endothelium (sometimes vertical line: Krukenberg spindle)
Pigment on posterior lens capsule (Zentmayer’s line)
Pigment on anterior hyaloid-capsular ligament (Egger’s line)
Increased prevalence of retinal tears and retinal detachment

sections.title: Retinal Safety Alert
content: Regular checks of peripheral retina are required due to lattice degeneration risk
Small risk of inducing retinal detachment with miotics due to myopia/lattice

sections.title: Gonioscopy Findings
content: Pigment may be anterior to Schwalbe’s line inferiorly

sections.title: Pigmentary Glaucoma Progression
sections.content: Glaucoma may develop in 33–50% of patients with PDS. Usually asymptomatic, but blurred vision, haloes, and red eye(s) may occur after acute pigment shedding following mydriasis or exercise. Features include increased IOP ± corneal oedema (if acute), features of PDS, and disc changes/VF defects as for POAG (Primary open-angle glaucoma).

sections.title: Other Insidious Syndromes & References
sections.content: Other glaucoma syndromes which may present in an insidious manner include: inflammatory open angle, red cell, ghost cell, phacolytic, Posner–Schlossman syndrome, Schwartz–Matsuo syndrome in rrD (all open angle), and surgically induced angle closure (tight scleral buckle, PK). For syndromes that typically present in an acute/subacute manner, see Table 10.4. (Refer to PDS/Pigmentary Glaucoma context on p. 402-403, and POAG details on pp. 390-391).
